(d) The five-year accident history
The Bendix Warehouse has been operated as Royal Adhesives & Sealants, LLC since 2016 and from that time to the present, has had an excellent record of preventing injuries and accidental releases. Within the last 5-years, Bendix Warehouse has not had a Risk Management Program reportable accident with the specific consequences of on-site death(s), injuries, significant property damage and/or off-site death(s), injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

(e) The emergency response program
The Bendix Warehouse emergency response program is written in an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) format which is intended to respond to contingencies that integrates the requirements of multiple government agencies into one combined document. A contingency can be a spill, release, fire, earthquake, traffic accident, or any other foreseeable emergency condition that threatens the environment, public safety, employees in a workplace, or other specified subjects; and that would require an emergency response of some kind. The plan is designed to ensure that the facility has the necessary resources available to effectively respond to emergency incidents and is designed and maintained to promote prompt and effective action intended to minimize hazards to human health and/or the environment if an emergency occurs.
Bendix Warehouse personnel are trained and expected to follow their Emergency Action Plan (EAP), in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38, and the guidelines contained in their Integrated Contingency Plan. If an incidental spill or release of a hazardous material is observed or discovere

7. Incident Investigation
The facility initiates incident investigations in accordance 40 CFR part 68. Additionally, the Bendix Warehouse procedure specifies that all accidental releases be investigated since minor accident or near miss investigations may help identify problems that could result in major releases if left unaddressed. Incident investigation findings are promptly addressed to prevent recurrence. Proprietary EHS incident software is used to document incidents along with incident findings and root causes. The software includes an element that tracks action items to completion. The H.B. Fuller corporate incident reporting procedure defines when a root cause analysis must be performed. The Cause Map methodology is the default methodology used for root cause analyses. Other methodologies may be utilized at the discretion of the facilitator.
8. Management of Change
A written Management of Change (MoC) procedure is used at the facility to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, organization, and procedures that would affect the covered processes. MoC requirements prior to start-up includes informing and training all employees and applicable contractors affected by the change. Prior to start-up all relevant documents are updated such as Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, and Standard Operating Procedures.

5. Mechanical Integrity 
The facility has a written Mechanical Integrity Program that is critical to safe operations in the Aerosol Canister/Can Filling Process and Aerosol Storage Area #1. The written program includes preventive maintenance, required inspections and tests (ITPM) using recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices, follows a schedule that matches the manufacturer's recommendations or more frequently if prior operating experience indicates is necessary and documents each ITPM activity in accordance with regulatory requirements. Examples of process equipment receiving ITPM include pressure vessels, storage containers, piping systems, fire protection/fire suppression system, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Equipment deficiencies are corrected before further use of process equipment or whenever necessary to ensure safety. Criteria or rationale used to establish ITPM frequency along with a test and inspection schedule is established. Procedures are established addressing the use, removal, or replacement of equipment out of specification. Written test procedures are maintained on all ITPM performed and all ITPM work is performed by trained personnel. Also, training of process maintenance employees includes an overview of the process and its hazards and covers procedures applicable to safe job performance. The Mechanical Integrity (MI) Program contains a MI Quality Assurance element for new construction & equipment, newly installed equipment, maintenance materials, and spare parts & equipment.

Aerosol Storage Area #1 is the section of the warehouse where CAA Section 112(r) chemical mixtures are stored above their threshold quantities and was built in 2020 as a 92 ft. long x 40.2 ft. x 16 ft. high steel wire cage with steel wire top located in the northeast side of the warehouse for the storage of pressurized canisters (cylinders) that are classified as DOT Hazardous Materials Class 2.1-Flammable Gases (NFPA 704-Flammability 4 rating). (b) Bendix Warehouse and the Regulated Substances Handled
The Bendix Warehouse is in an industrial neighborhood on the West side of North Bendix Drive, in the northwestern section of the City of South Bend, Indiana. This 4.49-acre property was originally developed in 1975 with significant renovations occurring in 2016 and 2020 through 2023. It is bordered by South Bend International Airport to the north, wooded property to the west, parking lot of Duramold Castings to the south, railroad on the east and south, and roadway to the east. Other than small, landscaped strips along the building edges and a grassy area on the western edge of the property, areas surrounding structures are impervious, asphalt surfaces with storm drains that discharge to the City of South Bend Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Paved employee parking and loading dock areas are located on the southeastern side of the structure.  
The warehouse consists of an approximately 64,500-square foot building that occupies much of the property. It has only one occupant and their core, primary NAICS code is 49311-General Warehousing and Storage. The largest part of the facility consists of warehouse space and operates as a chemical warehouse that receives, stores and ships solvent and water-based industrial adhesives and sealants, commercial roofing adhesives, mirror mastics and epoxies as finished products to customers.
